name: OR DHS Cross Workspace DB Query

source:
## Connect to external DB using Spark.read with LinkedService credentials

##### To connect to an external dedicated SQL database located in another Synapse Workspace without using a username and password, _spark.read_ function can be applied using the Linkedservice credentials.

_Please note that the examples below require the right privileges to the database you are connecting to, outlined below:
create user [_synapse_identity_] from external PROVIDER;
exec sp_addrolemember 'db_datareader', '_synapse_identity_'
exec sp_addrolemember 'd_owner', '_synapse_identity_'_

# third party packages
import sqlalchemy
import pyodbc
import pandas as pd
import urllib
import argparse # used by parse_args
import sys
import datetime
import os

!pip install mssql

sql_server_name = "rayfelipesynapseworkspace"
db_port = 1433
db_name = "dedpool1"
linked_service_name = "AzureSynapseAnalytics1"
access_token = mssparkutils.credentials.\
getConnectionStringOrCreds(linked_service_name)

db_table = "dbo.students"

# Read a table, store results in a dataframe
# df = spark.read.format("com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.spark") \
df = spark.read.format("jdbc") \
    .option("url", "jdbc:sqlserver://%s.database.windows.net:%d" % \
    (sql_server_name, db_port)) \
    .option("dbtable", db_table) \
    .option("accessToken", access_token) \
    .option("encrypt", "true") \
    .option("databaseName", db_name) \
    .option("hostNameInCertificate", "*.database.windows.net") \
    .load()

df.show()

# Query another table

##### To query another table, a new spark.read call can be initated.

# Read another table, store results in a dataframe
db_table = "dbo.classroom"
df = spark.read.format("com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.spark") \
    .option("url", "jdbc:sqlserver://%s.database.windows.net:%d" % \
    (sql_server_name, db_port)) \
    .option("dbtable", db_table) \
    .option("accessToken", access_token) \
    .option("encrypt", "true") \
    .option("databaseName", db_name) \
    .option("hostNameInCertificate", "*.database.windows.net") \
    .load()

df.show()

# Streamline _spark.read_ to a database having multiple tables

##### The option above is not efficient because several _spark.read_ is required for each table in a database that needs querying. Therefore, to avoid creating multiple spark.reads to multiple tables, use a _for loop_

table_list = ["dbo.students","dbo.classroom"]
# The table list above will be created by the notebook developer, 
    #in the assumption that they know which tables they need to work on.

for i in table_list:
    df = spark.read.format("com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.spark") \
        .option("url", "jdbc:sqlserver://%s.database.windows.net:%d" % \
        (sql_server_name, db_port)) \
        .option("dbtable", i) \
        .option("accessToken", access_token) \
        .option("encrypt", "true") \
        .option("databaseName", db_name) \
        .option("hostNameInCertificate", "*.database.windows.net") \
        .load()
    df.show()

# Use full SQL statements when working with data

##### You can use SQL statements to analyze data using _SparkSession_ along with _spark.sql_.

from pyspark.sql import SparkSession

# Delete tempview if it already exist, then create one
spark.catalog.dropTempView("tempview")
df.createTempView("tempview")

# Example query to demonstrate full SQL capability
sql = "SELECT * FROM tempview where subject = 'history'"
df = spark.sql(sql)

df.show()

# Use SparkSession with managed identity enabled

##### This approach, as you will see below, does not require _access tokens_ compared to the options above. Instead, it uses the managed identity to connect to the external databases.

# Add required imports
import com.microsoft.spark.sqlanalytics
from com.microsoft.spark.sqlanalytics.Constants import Constants

from pyspark.sql import SparkSession

# Read from existing internal table
df = (spark.read
    .option(Constants.SERVER, \
    "rayfelipesynapseworkspace.sql.azuresynapse.net")
    .synapsesql("dedpool1.dbo.classroom")
    # Column-pruning i.e., query select column values.
    .select("*")
    )

# Show contents of the dataframe
df.show()

# Create a temp view for running SQL statements
spark.catalog.dropTempView("tempview")
df.createTempView("tempview")

sql = "SELECT * FROM tempview where subject = 'physics'"
df = spark.sql(sql)

# Show contents of dataframe after SQL with where clause
df.show()

# Persist the data in a Lake Database

##### The data result, i.e. the Dataframe, can be perisisted in a Lake Database using standard SQL statements.
spark.sql("CREATE DATABASE IF NOT EXISTS raytemp11db")
